name: Danu

attributes.attribute: daughter of the wilderness goddess Flidais

sources: Condren, Mary. The Serpent and the Goddess: Women, Religion and Power in Ancient Ireland. San Francisco: Harper & Row, 1989, 57.
Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.
text:
Possible rephrased text:

An Irish goddess known by several names, such as Danu, Dana, Anu and possibly Donand or Danann, has been associated with the knowledge and the land's fertility. While no myths about her have survived, many place-names, such as the Dane Hills, the Danube river in eastern Europe, and the Paps Of Danu in Munster, reflect her name or her likeness. Most significantly, the Tuatha Dé Danann, the divine race believed to represent the gods of the Celts, were called "the people of the goddess Danu," which implies her importance in the pantheon. However, as the Tuatha Dé Danann were later demoted and diminished to fairyfolk in folktale figures, Danu's role as a goddess suffered a similar fate. Scholars have suggested a possible connection between Danu and DÔN, the Welsh mother goddess, as well as a possible kinship with the mighty Dagda, the god of abundance, and Flidais, the goddess of the wilderness. Some texts identify her as the mother of the Sons Of Tuireann. For more information, see Anu.
